pullRequest.title: 1365/ Add ToastCompat with support for dark toasts on pre-R
pullRequest.bodyText:
I started implementing this using theme attributes, but then I noticed there was an in-app night mode. I tried to follow this approach which means that the system "Night mode" will have no effect on the color of the toast.

nodes.bodyText:
It's not possible for us to change the colors without getting a reference to the Toast itself because:

the attribute it uses for the background is private
it doesn't use attributes for the text color - it's hardcoded
There's no built-in constant for this (potentially because the target/compile SDK of this app is 28).

Toast.getView() and Toast.setView() are deprecated in Android R. I read (somewhere) that getView() will return null, and I don't know what the behaviour of setView() will be, though I wouldn't be surprised if it's a no-op on Android R (if targetSdkVersion >= 30).
I wasn't able to test on R, so I left this with a guard. This means that on R and above, unless this logic is amended, toasts will do whatever they do by default, which means that the toast will be light colored.
⚠️  I have not tested this on anything apart from API 29.
I continued to use the same IDs that the default Toast layout used.
I've seen getNightModeTextBrightness() used elsewhere, but with 255 hardcoded. Is that preferred?
This should always be tinted - if the toast looks red, something is not correct 😅

nodes.bodyText: let's play it safe here and do nothing if it's null just in case Samsung devices do something odd

if Toast.getView() is not deprecated until R and we're only supporting this R and below, could we not just let the normal Toast ui inflate itself, get its view, and if it's not null, apply a background instead?

i think for the alpha, it's fine to hardcode to 255 here since we don't want the background to be very transparent and perhaps not very readable? as a matter of fact i am ok with adding a toast_text_color_night (until we support day/night) and just using a nice value for that instead of making it customizable
